newsitem.title: UK: UK Treasury denies rumours sterling to rejoin ERM.
newsitem.headline: UK Treasury denies rumours sterling to rejoin ERM.

text.p: The British Treasury moved quickly on Thursday to dampen speculation that Britain planned to rejoin the EU's Exchange Rate Mechanism (ERM) at a central rate of 2.50 marks in 2001.
Responding to an overnight news wire report, which quoted a Labour Party source as saying sterling should rejoin the ERM at 2.50 marks, a Treasury spokeswoman said: "There is no truth in it at all."
The pound lost around four pfennigs overnight on the report carried by Bridge news agency although it has since recopued around half a pfennig.

Earlier, Goldman Sachs chief economist Gavyn Davies said that such rumours were inevitable given the new Labour government's more pro-European stance. Davies is widely tipped to be appointed to the newly created post of second Bank of England deputy governor.

Sterling left the ERM in September 1992, after the government found it impossible to keep the currency near the then 2.95 central rate. The system was designed as a pre-cursor to a single European currency.

Labour, which scored a landslide victory over the ruling Conservative Party in last Thursday's election, has said that Britain in unlikely to join the single European currency in the first wave in 1999 and any future decision to join would be subject to test of the national interest and a referendum. -- London Newsroom +44 171 542 2774
